Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996- Ss.11 and 12-Appointment of an arbitrator by a party/official/authority having interest in dispute or outcome - Impermissibility of - Independence and impartiality of the arbitrator - Necessity of - Two categories of cases/agreements under consideration were: (i) where the Managing Director himself is named as an arbitrator with an additional power to appoint any other person as an arbitrator; and (ii) where the Managing Director is not to act as an arbitrator himself but is empowered or authorised to appoint any other person of his choice or discretion as an arbitrator - Vis-a-vis the first category: TRF, (2017) 8 SCC 377, inter alia held that once the arbitrator has become ineligible by operation of law, he cannot nominate another as an arbitrator and that the arbitrator becomes ineligible as per prescription contained in S. 12(5) (i.e. the ineligibility referred to was as a result of operation of law, in that a person having an interest in the dispute or in the outcome or decision thereof, must not only be ineligible to act as an arbitrator but must also not be eligible to appoint anyone else as an arbitrator) - Applying the said test to the second category, held, if the interest that the person concerned has in the outcome of the dispute, is taken to be the basis for the possibility of bias, it will always be present irrespective of whether the matter stands under the first or second category of cases - Thus, a party or an official or an authority having interest in the dispute, held, is also disentitled to make appointment of an arbitrator (Paras 18 to 24) B. Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 - S. 11 Short delay in appointment of arbitrator by the party contractually required to do so - Insufficiency of, for exercising power of appointment under S. 11 - Communication invoking arbitration in terms of Cl. 24 was sent by the applicants on 28-6-2019 and the period within which the respondent was to make the necessary appointment expired on 28-7-2019 - The next day was a working day but the appointment was made on Tuesday, 30-7-2019 - Held, technically, the appointment was not within the time stipulated but such delay on part of the respondent could not be said to be an infraction of such magnitude that exercise of power by the Court under S. 11 is called for (Para 15) As an executing agency of Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, the respondent was desirous of comprehensive architectural planning and designing for the works provided under Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojna ("PMSSY"). Therefore a request for proposals bearing RFP No. HSCC/3-AIIMS/Guntur/2016 was issued on 15-7-2016. In response to the RFP, the consortium of the applicants, namely, (i) Perkins Eastman Architects DPC, an architectural firm having its registered office in New York, and (ii) Edifice Consultants (P) Ltd ., having its office in Mumbai submitted their bid on 28-9-2016. Letter of intent was issued on 31-1-2017 awarding the project to the applicants, the consideration being Rs 15.63 crores. A letter of award was issued in favour of the applicants on 22-2-2017 and a contract was entered into between the applicants and the respondent on 22-5-2017, which provided inter alia for dispute resolution in Clause 24. The relevant portion of said clause was as under: "24.0. DISPUTE RESOLUTION (ii) Except where the decision has become final, binding and conclusive in terms of sub-para (i) above disputes or difference shall be referred for adjudication through arbitration by a sole arbitrator appointed by the CMD HSCC within 30 days from the receipt of request from the Design Consultant. " a b C d e By letter dated 28-6-2019 the Chief Managing Director of the respondent was f called upon to appoint a sole arbitrator in terms of said Clause 24. However, no appointment of an arbitrator was made within thirty days but a letter was addressed by Chief General Manager of the respondent on 30-7-2019 purportedly appointing one Major General K.T. Gajria as the sole arbitrator. An application was then filed under Section 11(6) read with Section 11(12)(a) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 ("the A&C Act") and under the g Appointment of Arbitrators by the Chief Justice of India Scheme, 1996 ("the Scheme") praying for the following principal relief: "(a) appoint a sole arbitrator, in accordance with Clause 24 of the contract dated 22-5-2017 executed between the parties and the sole arbitrator so appointed may adjudicate the disputes and differences between the parties arising from the said contract." h ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. HSCC (INDIA) LTD. 763 The respondent contended that two basic submissions were raised in Para 3 in sub-paras (z) and (aa) of the application that the Chairman and Managing Director failed to appoint the sole arbitrator within 30 days of the requisition dated 28-6-2019 and that it was the Chief General Manager of the respondent who purportedly made the appointment of a sole arbitrator on 30-7-2019. The infirmities thus projected were on two counts, namely, for overstepping the limit of 30 days; and secondly, the appointment was not made by the Chairman and Managing Director of the respondent. It was pointed out that the period in terms of requisition dated 28-6-2019 expired on Friday and the appointment was made on the first available working day. Secondly, the appointment was actually made by the Chairman and Managing Director but was conveyed by the Chief General Manager, and as such the alleged infirmities were completely non-existent. It was further submitted that arbitration, if any, in the instant matter would not be an international commercial arbitration. The issues involved in this application were: (i) Whether the arbitration in the present case would be an international commercial arbitration i.e. whether the Supreme Court cannot deal with the application under Section 11(6) read with Section 11(12)(a) of the A&C Act, 1996? (ii) Whether a case was made out for exercise of power by the Court to make an appointment of an arbitrator i.e.: (a) Whether Chairman and Managing Director failed to appoint the sole arbitrator within 30 days of the requisition dated 28-6-2019 and if so its consequences? (b) Whether Chairman and Managing Director was ineligible to nominate an arbitrator i.e. whether a person having an interest in the dispute or in the outcome or decision thereof, must not only be ineligible to act as an arbitrator but must also not be eligible to appoint anyone else as an arbitrator? (c) Whether power can be exercised by the Supreme Court under Section 11 of the Act when the appointment of an arbitrator has already been made by the respondent? Allowing the application, the Supreme Court Held: On whether the arbitration in the present case would be an international commercial arbitration It is not disputed by the respondent that it was a requisite condition to declare a g lead member of the Consortium and that by aforesaid declaration Applicant 1 was shown to be the lead member of the Consortium. The reliance is however placed by the respondent on Clause 9 of the Consortium Agreement by virtue of which both the applicants would be jointly and severally responsible for the execution of the project. It is clear that the declaration shows that Applicant 1 was accepted to be the lead member of the Consortium. Even if the liability of both the applicants h was stated in Clause 9 to be joint and several, that by itself would not change the status of Applicant 1 to be the lead member. For example, under Section 2(31) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, "person" is defined as including, under sub-clause (v), an association of persons, or body of individuals, whether incorporated or not. It is in this sense, that an association is referred to in Section 2(1)(j)(iii) which would therefore include a consortium consisting of two or more bodies corporate, at least one of whom is a body corporate incorporated in a country other than India. (Para 12) The lead member of the Consortium company i.e. Applicant 1 being an architectural firm having its registered office in New York, requirements of Section 2(1)(j) of the A&C Act are satisfied and the arbitration in the present case would be an " international commercial arbitration". (Para 13) L&T-SCOMi v. MMRDA, (2019) 2 sec 271 : (2019) 1 sec (Civ) 609,followed TDM Infrastructure (P) Ltd. v. UE Development (India) (P) Ltd. , (2008) 14 SCC 271 , cited On whether a case has been made out for exercise of power by the Court for an appointment of an arbitrator On delay The communication invoking arbitration in terms of Clause 24 was sent by the applicants on 28-6-2019 and the period within which the respondent was to make the necessary appointment expired on 28-7-2019. The next day was a working day but the appointment was made on Tuesday, 30-7-2019. Technically, the appointment was not within the time stipulated but such delay on part of the respondent could not be said to be an infraction of such magnitude that exercise of power by the Court under Section 11 of the A&C Act merely on that ground is calle d for. (Para 15) On ineligibility of Chairman and Managing Director to nominate an arbitrator Once the arbitrator has become ineligible by operation of law, he cannot nominate another as an arbitrator. The arbitrator becomes ineligible as per prescription contained in Section 12(5) of the A&C Act. It is inconceivable in law that person who is statutorily ineligible can nominate a person. Needless to say, once the infrastructure collapses, the superstructure is bound to collapse. One cannot have a building without the plinth. Or to put it differently, once the identity of the Managing Director as the sole arbitrator is lost, the power to nominate someone else as an arbitrator is obliterated. (Para 18) We thus have two categories of cases. The first, where the Managing Director himself is named as an arbitrator with an additional power to appoint any other person as an arbitrator. In the se cond category, the Managing Director is not to act as an arbitrator himself but is empowered or authorised to appoint any other person of his choice or discretion as an arbitrator. If, in the first category of cases, the Managing Director was found incompetent, it was because of the interest that he would be said to be having in the outcome or result of the dispute. The element of invalidity would thus be directly relatable to and arise from the interest that he would be having in such outcome or decision. If that be the test, similar invalidity would always arise and spring even in the second category of cases.
